transcripts: Morty, when you've got massive optimization problems like finding the shortest route through a hundred cities, checking every possible solution would take longer than the heat death of the universe.
Uh, okay Rick, so what do we do instead?
Local search, Morty. You just pick a random starting point, look at the solutions right next to it, and move to whichever one's better.
So it's like, uh, climbing a hill when you can't see very far?
Exactly! You keep stepping upward until you can't go any higher. You won't always reach the absolute peak, but you'll get somewhere pretty decent.
And the longer we do this, the better our answer gets?
Bingo, Morty. It's not perfect, but it beats waiting billions of years for the "optimal" solution.
Alright Morty, imagine chess but with math. Every possible move creates a branching tree of game states, and you need to pick the path that screws you over the least.
Wait, screws me over the least? Shouldn't I try to win?

That's the thing - minimax assumes your opponent isn't an idiot. You maximize your advantage, they minimize it. So you work backwards from the endgame asking "what's the best I can do if they play perfectly?"
So like, I'm planning for them to make the smartest possible move against me?
Exactly. You calculate every branch assuming optimal play from both sides. The minimax value is the best outcome you can guarantee yourself against a perfect opponent.
Oh, so it's like the worst-case scenario but in a good way?
Bingo Morty. Plan for the worst, hope for human error.
Alright Morty, minimax finds the perfect move but it's stupidly slow because it checks every possible game. Alpha-beta pruning fixes that by cutting off useless branches.
Wait, how does it know which branches are useless?

Simple. We track two numbers - alpha is your best guaranteed score, beta is your opponent's best guaranteed score. If you find a move where your opponent can screw you over worse than what you already have locked in, you stop looking.
So like, if I already found a way to win 5 points, and I'm looking at a path where my opponent can hold me to 3 points, I just give up on that path?
Exactly! Your opponent's not an idiot, Morty. They'll never let you take the better path anyway. Same optimal move, way less computation.
That's actually pretty smart. So we still get the perfect answer but faster?
Bingo. It's like having a crystal ball that tells you when you're wasting your time.
